item.title: Covid: UK's furlough scheme starts to wind down
item.description: Employers will start paying part of workers' furlough wages as the job support scheme is withdrawn.

item.title: CCP 100: Xi warns China will not be 'oppressed' in anniversary speech
item.description: The Chinese leader was speaking at an event marking the centenary of the ruling Communist Party.

item.title: Man apologises over Prof Chris Whitty park footage
item.description: Police are investigating the video which appears to show England's chief medical officer being accosted.

item.title: Covid common in pet cats and dogs, study finds
item.description: Pet owners with Covid could infect about 20% of cats and dogs, although most symptoms are mild.

item.title: Right to repair rules will extend lifespan of products, government says
item.description: Appliances will be cheaper to run, the government says, under plans that will extend the lifespan of household goods.

item.title: Wimbledon 2021: Andy Murray beats Oscar Otte in second-round thriller
item.description: Andy Murray reaches the Wimbledon third round after beating German qualifier Oscar Otte in another thriller finishing under the lights.

item.title: William and Harry to unveil Diana statue at Kensington Palace
item.description: It will be unveiled at Diana's former home, Kensington Palace, on what would have been her 60th birthday.

item.title: 'My heart was ripped from my chest'
item.description: Pablo Rodríguez's mother and grandmother were in a Miami apartment building when it collapsed.

item.title: Pupil self-isolation Covid impact 'not monitored'
item.description: The government cannot say how many infections are being prevented by sending pupils home.

item.title: Bill Cosby freed after top court overturns sexual assault conviction
item.description: The US comedian leaves jail hours after a Pennsylvania court overturned his sexual assault conviction.

item.title: Trump Organization indicted in tax investigation, US media report
item.description: Specific charges against the former president's company are expected to be made public on Thursday.

item.title: Gap to close all 81 stores in UK and Ireland
item.description: The fashion chain says it will be online-only from the end of September.

item.title: Covid: NHS plans booster jab for those 50 and over before winter
item.description: The UK's vaccine committee says winter could see spikes in flu and Covid, putting pressure on the NHS.

item.title: The Papers: 'Jab in each arm' plans, and 'mass events fear'
item.description: Thursday's papers include vaccine booster plans, fears over big events and England's Euro 2020 quarter-final.

item.title: How a US teen developed an app to help his sister talk
item.description: Sixteen-year-old Archer Calder developed an app to help his nonverbal sister Della communicate.

item.title: Covid-19 furlough scheme starts to be scaled back
item.description: As financial support reduces, we hear from a worker who has been on and off furlough for 15 months.

item.title: Mozambique attack: Timeline of terror
item.description: Some of those caught up in the attack on the northern city of Palma by Islamist militants share their stories.

item.title: 100-year-old celebrates birthday by climbing O2 in wheelchair
item.description: Harry White, a veteran from east London, climbs the O2 to celebrate his 100th birthday.

item.title: Royal Mail delivers letter addressed to 'woman in Cornwall shed'
item.description: The note to an author "near a village 21 miles from Land's End" finds its intended recipient.

item.title: Nick Grimshaw to leave Radio 1 after 14 years
item.description: The drivetime host says working on the station has been a "childhood dream come true".

item.title: Royal photographer: 'Diana broke the mould'
item.description: The Duke of Cambridge and the Duke of Sussex are set to unveil a statue in memory of Diana, Princess of Wales.

item.title: Theatrics or threat: How to handle China's Communist party at 100
item.description: There is much debate about how to deal with the country's authoritarian politics, reports the BBC's John Sudworth.

item.title: Covid: Misleading stat claims more vaccinated people die
item.description: Vaccines reduce the risk of death but do not eliminate it completely.

item.title: King's Lynn: The community shop with a chair for those who 'are not OK'
item.description: A community tells how its local shop has helped it cope during the pandemic and lockdowns.

item.title: The Easter Island pianist playing for her home's future
item.description: Mahani Teave returned to the world's most remote inhabited island to help preserve its culture.

item.title: The Amazon sellers who sold up and became millionaires
item.description: Small e-commerce entrepreneurs have thrived in lockdown - now big money wants to buy them out.

item.title: Cillian Murphy is sorry for everything in poignant post-apocalyptic film
item.description: All of This Unreal Time, which premieres in Manchester this week, charts a man's existential journey.

item.title: Bill Cosby: The rise, fall and release of 'America's Dad'
item.description: Once a national treasure, the comedian was jailed for sexual assault but that conviction has now been overturned.

item.title: Diana statue: What next for William and Harry's relationship?
item.description: Sources say communications have been minimal - with deep upset and mistrust on both sides.

item.title: US-Canada weather: Visual guide to the heatwave
item.description: Maps, graphics and charts explaining the Canada and north-west US heatwave, with temperatures at nearly 50C.

item.title: Jadon Sancho - A hybrid of the modern age
item.description: What can Manchester United fans expect from Jadon Sancho, who is returning to England four years after joining Borussia Dortmund.

item.title: Black Widow: Scarlett Johansson's 'rousing' Marvel film impresses most critics
item.description: But some reviewers take issue with how the Marvel superhero film handles the exploitation of women.

item.title: Hong Kong: How life has changed under China's national security law
item.description: Seven city residents tell the BBC how the national security law fundamentally changed their lives.

item.title: Wimbledon 2021: Roger Federer says grass is 'slippery under roof' after Mannarino & Williams injuries
item.description: After Serena Williams and Adrian Mannarino injure themselves on Centre Court, BBC Sport looks at why grass courts are slippery and what impact it can have.

item.title: Brexit: What's the Northern Ireland Protocol?
item.description: Why are there now some border checks between Great Britain and Northern Ireland?

item.title: Batley and Spen by-election: What's at stake for the main political parties?
item.description: The constituency will be electing a new MP on Thursday, but the parties contesting the seat have a lot riding on the result.

item.title: Mature Dunkley guides England to tense ODI win against India
item.description: Sophia Dunkley's unbeaten 73 helps England beat India by five wickets in the second ODI and take a 6-2 lead in the series.

item.title: 'Benitez at Everton - an inspired risk or certain to turn toxic?'
item.description: Rafael Benitez to Everton is one of the most unlikely Premier League stories of recent times, which could prove unexpectedly inspired - or have the capacity to become toxic, writes Phil McNulty.

item.title: 'We don't have any days to lose' - Nuno wants fast start as Tottenham boss
item.description: Tottenham appoint former Wolves boss Nuno Espirito Santo as their new manager on a two-year contract.

item.title: 'Not bad for a part-time player' - Kyrgios wins epic match 9-7 in fifth set
item.description: Matteo Berrettini's fine form continues and Nick Kyrgios comes through a thrilling five sets to reach round two at Wimbledon.

item.title: 'I never thought battle for gender equity would be hardest' - Bujold Tokyo-bound after appeal win
item.description: Canadian boxer Mandy Bujold will compete in this summer's Olympics after a successful appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport.

item.title: Wimbledon 2021: Novak Djokovic, Aryna Sabalenka and Venus Williams in day three highlights
item.description: Watch some of the best moments from day three at Wimbledon including Katie Boulter's brilliant performance against Aryna Sabalenka and a ball boy's woes.

item.title: England Women v India Women: Kate Cross takes five wickets
item.description: Watch Kate Cross take the second five-wicket haul of her one-day career during England's five-wicket victory over India in the second one-day international at Taunton.

item.title: The EU’s vaccine passport and what it means for travel
item.description: The EU's vaccine passport - its Digital Covid Certificate - is being rolled out across all 27 nations.

item.title: Covid: How is furlough changing and when will it end?
item.description: Furlough has been extended until the end of September

item.title: What are the rules about self-isolating, testing and masks in schools?
item.description: The government wants to change the rules which mean entire classes must self-isolate after a positive case.

item.title: How many cases are in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Millions of people most vulnerable to Covid-19 may be offered a third vaccination in September.

item.title: British Jews' fear and defiance amid record monthly anti-Semitism reports
item.description: Some 460 anti-Semitic incidents were reported to the Community Security Trust from 8 May to 7 June.

item.title: Covid quarantine hotels: Women say they were sexually harassed by guards
item.description: One woman tells the BBC a security guard employed by G4S mimed sex while they were alone in a lift.

item.title: A fake wedding, and a $250,000 scam
item.description: How a British man's dreams of a future with his Ukrainian fiancee ended in financial disaster.

item.title: Gary Allen: The killer who nearly got away with murder
item.description: Gary Allen's conviction for the murders of two women brings a 20-year quest for justice to an end.

item.title: The Lazarus heist: How North Korea almost pulled off a billion-dollar hack
item.description: In 2016 North Korean hackers planned a $1bn raid on Bangladesh's national bank and came within an inch of success. But how did they do it?
